review_title: Don't work here if you value your sanity
pros:
lots of hours 
comradery in misery
cons:
poor staffing - not the staffs fault mind you, just running on absolutely skeleton staff at all times
corporate doesn't care how behind you get on prescriptions due to staffing. they know this will result in more customer abuse but they don't care. tell you to promise people 15 minute wait times, how can I promise 15 minutes with 15 other people waiting and a total of three people in the pharmacy? One on register permanently, a pharmacist glued to the phone and desperately trying to verify, and the last running around trying to fill prescriptions, take in new prescriptions, get yelled at by customers who've been waiting, answering the endless phone calls etc. 
Corporate wanting us to shill more and more products and services to people. we can't even do the base of what a pharmacy is supposed to with the lack of hours for staff, why would patients ever sign up for more services that they know we can't provide. its awful.
lack of staffing in pharmacy is dangerous, coupled with intense pressure from customers and corporate alike. it makes mistakes more frequent, and I'm scared that CVS's way of management is going to get more patients killed.

The company itself does not fund for technology, so the store in Tempe was equipped with ancient devices that took an absurd amount of time to load, which were required to use for service. Majority of the time, lines were long, just because the cash registers were slow or malfunctioning because they’re maybe 30+ years old (or at least they acted that old). The bathrooms had a cleaner that came in only once a week, making them kinda gross near the end of a week’s worth of work. The Mill Ave store in Tempe attracted way too much homeless and crime, which the management had no idea how to handle. I had to personally call the police at least 10 times in the span of 2 weeks, just for reference. Management never allowed you to take sick days because they lacked additional workers— entirely inefficient and horrible, for when you physically couldn’t make it into work. The current employers at the Mill Ave harassed workers for requesting time off and made a big deal when requesting to take off work, to get the Covid Vaccine (which is totally bizarre, considering that it’s a HEALTH retail store). All in all, the management sucked and the store is ran by a bunch of bozos and overly ancient microwave computers.

job_title: Certified Pharmacy Technician (CPhT) in Manchester, England
pros:
If you have good coworkers, you guys can take comfort in how understaffed and awful it can be working here.
Pay has the potential to be good for retail-type work.
Cool managers make work much better
cons:
Awful managers and slow pharmacists can make work a sluggish hell to work through.
Horribly understaffed at most times.
Drive-thru moves painfully slow, can be issue after issue after issue, and ruin the workflow in a matter of 15-20 minutes.
Highly Stressful.
Metrics, metrics, metrics! You are pushed to fill as many scripts as possible, give as many shots as possible, and basically annoy the customer until they either get upset enough to say something, belittle you even though its automated, or just stop coming.
You are apologizing all day long for taking so long, but theres nothing you can do cause you are stuck with maybe 70 RXs overdue, there's a huge line at drive thru, customers down the aisle at pickup, some annoyed or annoying lady at drop off dropping her keys at drop off to get your attention, or the phones are ringing off the hook with 8 pharmacy calls. 
This job is truly a dead end, unless you want to be a pharmacist. Do not expect you hard work to go noticed.

job_title: Operations Supervisor in Laguna Woods, CA
pros: Pros would be that you meet some amazing people and you go thru a lot with them.
cons: The company is constantly cutting hours which adds to stress on upper management. It’s very hard to get your work done when you are short staffed and still offering great customer service. High volume stores  open with 2 people has 1 mid and closes with 2 people.  Low volume stores 1 opens til about 10 when cashier comes in and then a closer with maybe a 4 hour shift cashier. There are times where you have to count the money and be the cashier at the same time.  Counting the money is a very time consuming task. The computer system is very outdated. Some companies the closing procedure takes 15min, cvs closing take an hour sometimes more. The company really only cares about number on a sheet. Make the numbers and you are left alone.  It is also hard to move up internally. Raises suck and they cap out.  A kid in my store quit because they gave him a 2 cent raise. Usually you get 30cents every year.  I was with the company for 15 years and i was making the same as new hires.

review_title: Low-ball pay for the tech jobs, benefits are horrid, go elsewhere if you've got options
pros: The work/life balance is pretty good, although you will have to do deployments overnight. Individual teams can be awesome, once the right people are moved in and you get in sync.
cons:
Executive management seems to have their heads in the clouds and can't see the forest for the trees; we've lost vendors and entire consultant teams because they didn't start negotiating in time. They don't want to convert the good contractors into FTEs. There is very little camraderie or celebration of achievement in the wider project. The communication between teams is horrendous, with frequent environment outages which stop work for hours or days. Directors seem to nitpick over cosmetics and minor things from 1000 miles away, like when you sign into Teams or emailing them to tell them you're out sick, and not the quality of your work. They do not take criticism or input well. The department has been reorganized twice in a year, and we're losing good people left and right for better opportunities or FTE positions. Support for diversity is mostly performative, but there are plenty of women in leadership and as developers at least. No real neurodiversity or LGBT+ support that I've seen; all of our products still only use male and female. I'm the only non-binary or autistic person I've encountered.

I don't see any opportunity to advance, either, as a developer. I'll probably have to leave the company for a new title or new responsibilities. We learn a lot, but that's mostly because of individual people being willing to teach you stuff if you ask questions and having to wear multiple hats because they're not going to hire enough developers. There is no organized skill development.

pros: Pharmacy manager was so caring, most co-workers were really nice and easily to work with
cons:
Was okay up until covid. After the roll-out of covid-19 vaccines, I left work crying everyday. I was overworked and made minimum wage as a pharmacy technician. The company will give the lowest possible raise- almost insulting. I think corporate changed my pay from 15.00 to 15.33 per hour. As a very experienced pharmacy technician. My pharmacy manager thought I deserved more and fought them, and the best they could do was 16.50. The customers treated us like dirt and corporate didn’t care how badly we were treated. It was actual abuse. Until recently pharmacists did not have a break and worked 12 hrs per day (completely illegal). 

I’m so glad I left, I’m so much happier. Shortly after I left, the pharmacist needed to go on medical leave for mental health related issues. The district leader was upset and “wished he gave him more notice”, as if that is something that’s even planned. Another time one of my coworkers was called into work during a blizzard and the pharmacist was supposed to bring her. He got stuck, & her parents did not feel comfortable with an Uber driving her during the blizzard, and corporate STILL told her she needed to go in (she didn’t go thank goodness).

The safety in the stores is another big issue, especially here in NYC. Everyday we here about shoplifting or armed robberies or break-ins. My friend recently started at a store as a manager (should have consulted with me first), and every day he tells me “there was more shoplifting”. As employees we are told not to do anything. Even worse, some NYC stores have security guards who still let the stores get shoplifted. They honestly don’t provide any security. 

This company needs to do more for their employees. There’s a reason why their is a retail pharmacy crisis, with everyone quitting. It’s not because we’re lazy, it’s because we couldn’t take anymore abuse. I was considering pharmacy school until this place scared me away. Instead I went to get my MBA and I can tell you there is so much wrong with management at this company. It’s really simple, respect & protect your employees, pay them a fair salary (especially since pharmacy school is expensive), offer decent benefits, and don’t abuse the employees. This is the only way the company will ever reduce their turnover. CVS makes so much money and the company can afford to provide better wages and benefits to the employees. This company has profited so much from the covid 19 pandemic and hasn’t given anything to retail store employees. Everything is for corporate. They had an $18 million contract with NBC to do covid 19 testing and despite working 16 hr days, we didn’t see much of the profit. 

Anyway, I would not recommend CVS. Instead I got an internship at a small company that pays much more, offers employees lunch everyday, benefits, and management is very understanding.

job_title: Sales Associate/Cashier in Orange City, FL
pros: I happened to have an understanding boss. They were reasonable about non-holiday days off as long as you gave them notice. When we had to work holidays (you could pick which ones you wanted off and cross your fingers if you picked more than 2 days), there was a decent amount of hot, free food provided. We also got free food when working the day after hurricanes. Hardly any drama or gossip.
cons:
Pay was low, but it's retail. Barely any benefits besides store discounts / knowing where the clearance items are hidden. Putting up sale tag stickers every week is annoying and hurts your back, but there are plenty of retail stores that do it. While other retailers pay a little higher, for better or worse the store typically isn't very busy. 

You can work your way up by becoming an assistant manager, but when I asked assistant managers that had given their 2 week notice they said they only got a $.25 raise with twice the responsibility, and that you can be stuck at that position for over a decade. There's a lot of competition for store manager positions, and CVS will take advantage of you if you decide to work your way up. However, I didn't personally experience this since I stayed in the front of the store as a cashier.

review_title: Constantly increasing workload while cutting help. Management has zero understanding as to daily needs
pros: Good pay. Opportunities for growth if you're willing to go through their brown nosing, "we say jump you say how high" style leadership training.
cons:
Wayyyy too many vaccines. I don't mind giving vaccines, but they shouldn't constitute 75% of my daily work. It seems like corporate figured out vaccines are a huge money maker and now they have us pushing vaccines like an electronics store pushing extended warranties. Meanwhile on conference calls, they actually tell us "drink the kool aid" and that they don't care how bad the queue is and to give as many as possible. Maybe this job just not for me, but it feels unsafe and makes me fear for patient safety and my license.

The extra pay for being a manager is not worth the added headache. Stay a staff pharmacist if you can

They don't keep enough floaters on staff, so they rely on those of us already working full time to put in more hours to pick up the slack. Therefore, a lot of your time off requests get denied.

Conference calls. Usually at least once weekly to reiterate the same information they've probably emailed you twice already. I've also had more than I'd care to count last minute "quick" conference calls that go on for 30-45 minutes that easily could have been handled with a 100 word email

pros: Sadly, no pros whatsoever except that you're only scheduled btwn 40-45hrs per week.
cons:
In the short while I was with this company, I noticed a great many disturbing facts that made me regret accepting a management position with them such as:
1. During the interview process, the Regional Mngr lied to me about certain details of the job, how the training was gonna go, and how the company is "always hiring cause there's usually a revolving door when it comes to turnover".  After a month of me starting work, I found out from another senior level mngr that they were on a hiring-freeze due to "corporate restructuring". The training was a joke! I only got one week of minimal training before they started moving me to other low-performing stores to help out. They also expect u to complete your training modules on a tablet while you're working on the floor & have to score a 100% on all the assessments to pass. Lastly, after the first cpl months of me working there, the Regional Mngr didn't come to visit me in-person once to check how my training was going or talk to me about some of the issues I was having. She pretty much told me what I wanted to hear during the interview just to get me hired & throw me to the wolves.
2. Even if you're hired in any management role (or S.M.I.T. like I was given my 15yrs of mngt experience), you won't be able to act like an actual Mngr! Your subordinates walk all over u & refuse to listen to your simple directions cuz: not to sound like a sexist, but the majority of staff they hire r female who have trouble listening to a male authority figure & most importantly...they give all your subordinates the title of either Supervisor/Mngr (even the young ones in their late teens/early 20s who havent even finished school yet) so they can be given "over-ride" capabilities on the registers to scan items that need an I.D. check so the Store Mngr doesn't have to keep going up to the front of the store routinely to give them their over-ride. This is another reason y your underlings have a hard time listening to their "boss" cuz they all have a false sense of entitlement & think they know better than a experienced Mngr with 1.5 decades of experience.
3. They have VERY old equipment that'll make your job a living hell. According to an I.T. guy that has been working for company close to 25yrs who came to our store one day to help fix our automated checkout machines, when I asked him out of curiosity, he said the registers were a little over 20yrs old & the self-checkout machines were about 11-12yrs old. Not to mention the computer software in office is like from back during the floppy disk era & makes it very difficult to do management functions.
Take my advice, don't waste your time with this company!

pros: Steady income , okay pay and benefits
cons: Too much stress for the amount of pay.  Corporate is bottom line only.

pros: Easy to get promoted below the Store Manager position or to become a pharmacy technician with no prior experience
cons:
Short-staffing to the extreme, 

"Training" non-existent, you will be given "modules" to complete but will be rushed through them and supervisors will flat out encourage employees to complete them ASAP and skip the actual reading/paying attention to them. Taking too long on modules will result in write-ups.

unrealistic and/or impossible goals and metrics

supervisors who violate company policy and higher-ups who cover for them

working salaried employees well over contracted hours with no extra pay offered

stressful mentally and physically

fluctuating hours that can go from expecting you to work 70 hours one week to only giving you 5 hours the next due to ridiculous payroll budgets from corporate

HIGH turnover


toxic company culture

admonished by superiors for having a life outside of work

 schedule is supposed to be made 3 weeks out but that rarely happens so making plans and appointments is a nightmare, but if you do not take the shifts you are offered on your day off it will be assumed "you don't want any hours then."

Carepass signups push you into a salesperson position to the extent that you can get written up or fired for not meeting signup goals.

12 hour shifts are common and expected 

Depending on the store, you could be on your feet running register for 8 to 10 hours or more

Pharmacist expected to do too many things to the point it is a safety issue, typically only two or three techs scheduled as help due to low payroll hours from corporate

Front store expected to get a number of tasks completed daily with one or two people that, realistically, would require several to complete.

One person will be expected to run register, self-checkout, the photo lab, passport pictures, the phone, online orders, carepass sales, and provide "good customer service" to deter shoplifters, either alone or with a supervisor who will rarely (if ever) answer you when you call them.

One of the first things they try to get you to sign is a break waiver to skip lunch breaks. Taking 10-15 minute breaks is discouraged in front staff (even with 12 hours shifts) and pharmacy technicians are never allowed their 10-15 minute breaks, period.

Hostile pharmacy environment. Technicians are often gossipy, unprofessional, and hostile, especially to new people. New people basically train themselves because they just get used as register fodder so other techs can avoid the pickup station. Management doesn't care, ever. They are more concerned in keeping the experienced techs.

Long time employees are NOT valued. They stop giving raises to those that are "maxed out for the position" even if the maxed out employee is only making a few cents more than a new cashier starting out at the current $13 wage. I personally know an employee who has been with the company almost 40 years who is a shift manager that makes less than $15/hr.

Mentioning that: Even though it is against the law, they will punish you for discussing pay with other employees.

If you want anything higher than the OPs manager position you are expected to do anything asked by superiors without question. "They tell you to jump, you ask how high, no exceptions" which can mean anything from working at stores 4 hours away to working overnights to working 6 to 7 days a week constantly.

Maybe there are more pros if you have a position in corporate, but working store level is a nightmare.

pros: Great place to work at

pros: As always, my coworkers. Oddly, the pay.
cons:
They only allow you the hours for one keyholder, and one cashier per shift, if you are lucky. Many stores do not get even that liberty consistently. The sheer amount of time they want a manager to devote to potential employee theft, whilst letting customers walk right out with merch, is mind boggling. They want one person to stay in the “green zone” (front half of the store), to assist customers who cannot or will not use self checkout. That typically leaves the keyholder to handle all the grunt work in the back half: truck that is never ending, shelving overstock that can be on a second floor for many stores, etc. Regular weekly delivery is accepted blindly so counts are always off. There would not be time to scan it in anyway, considering the pittance number of payroll hours. However, there is also almost never time to have all replenishment 100%, so biweekly cycle counts are rarely 100%. Naturally, you are graded on all of these things.
Almost ALL of the difficulties front store and pharmacy face can be resolved with proper staffing. Proper oversight, enough hands to do jobs thoroughly and without exhausting anyone, enough time to properly develop low level staff, it would even greatly improve customer service levels because attitudes would be different. 
CVS is just another old boys club. Old ways, from old generations, with archaic ideas for how to treat staff. Even the pos systems are obscenely dated. Billions of dollars in profit, and profiteering, and zero used to improve where they started, front store and pharmacy. Payroll is a controllable expense, so let’s put all the stress on the in store salaried people that used to love their craft, so they overwork themselves, and kick all the money elsewhere. This corporation is the epitome of why the great resignation began.

review_title: This was the worst job I ever worked
pros: I thought there were pros. They fully pay for your training to become a state-registered tech and then national tech, but there are other jobs out there that don't need certification that will pay just as much. If you start out as a tech trainee you only make minimum wage. Is it worth it?
cons: Being a pharmacy tech is 90% dealing with customers some of which can be the meanest and nastiest people in your life. I saw far too many melt downs or screaming matches from customers, to not only us the employees, but sometimes each other. The hiring process is arduous and will leave stores severely short on staff and behind on scripts for months on end.

pros: Good salary. That's it. That's literally it.
cons:
- Workload required doesn't make up for the pay
- Whatever workload you start with, plan for it to increase while they take away help every year for eternity.
- Pharmacy staffing is straight up unsafe and unreasonable. See any number of news articles highlighting this problem from the last several years. 
- Critical mass of current employees exiting. They long term staff who know what they are doing are bailing, leaving an void of talent in a position that is not easily trained. 
- Speaking of training, you will receive none. It will be inadequate for what they will ask you to do almost immediately. Better hope you walk into a store with veteran staff. Wait, see previous point.
- Corporate management team that is completely out of touch with reality. They talk about caring about patients and employees while actively implementing plans that will make your job immediately harder.
- "Yes men" all the way up the chain. They are not interested in dissenting opinions from the minions actually in the stores. The decisions are made by a spreadsheet in Rhode island and you better get on board.
- They won't care about you as a person. You are an employee ID number. If you're lucky, you'll be asked before they volunteer you to cover shifts as people quit around you. If you're unlucky, you'll be scheduled 6 days a week for 10-12 hour shifts without your consent. Because "the district needs help".

job_title: Store Manager in Calif City, CA
pros: Pretty good pay, opportunity for growth
cons: Districts are being ran by mostly pharmacist who don’t understand the front store. Hours are cut drastically so there is almost no way you can perform to your potential. Nothing is ever the companies fault there is always a reason that it’s your fault even if hours were cut so bad that you spend a lot of time on the front end alone. I quit filling my prescriptions at CVS because of the dangerous conditions I seen in pharmacy. Overworked pharmacists and techs.

job_title: Benefits Verification Representative in Buffalo Grove, IL
pros: This is a safe job (it survived the pandemic), CVS has great benefits (rightfully so), and you can learn a lot in this role. It is also somewhat fulfilling because you are helping patients directly.
cons: Currently there is a pause on promotions within this position and this has been here for the past 6 months and it is very unfair to those employees who have been long overdue for a raise and promotion. Once you learn most of what you can in this job, it becomes very repetitive and boring. The management does not want to make any changes that would benefit employees or the patients, we have a new system that constantly causes issues with patients' prescription orders and people will receive a delay in therapy. There is little to no accountability with lazy work within this role, and it is very frustrating when you are a good worker that always does their job. You are underpaid **A LOT** for that they expect of you and how stressful things can be. There is little training and they expect you to learn most of it on the job and throw you into the fire.

job_title: Beauty Consultant in Rye Brook, NY
pros: If your coworkers are great and you have nice customers, the job is fine. Those are the only real pros.
cons: CVS corporate sucks. They don't care about you as an employee, they care about their bottom line. They technically give bonuses to beauty team members based on sales, but they have steadily cut away at the bonus percentage and made it more difficult to achieve, to the point where almost no beauty consultants I knew made a bonus by the time I left (and I understand it has only gotten worse). They set unrealistic sales goals, treat you like a child with their trainings, and then expect you to exclusively work the busiest store hours (which are usually mid-day shifts and weekends, so sorry if you want a social life). They don't want beauty people doing any of the physical parts of the job (like putting away weekly shipments or counting inventory), but don't give the store enough hours to have another employee do it correctly, so you either do it yourself and risk getting in trouble for it, or have to deal with your department being a mess. Oh, and they also expect you to offer flu shots and sign customers up for the store loyalty program as you offer assistance, which is a joke.

review_title: Lots and lots and lots and lots of layers

cons: The size also works against it as there are many layers and it can be super time consuming to find the right department or the singular person when questions arise. Culture is fairly uninspiring and by and large, coworkers are very focused on what is detailed in their job description - not a lot of teamwork or willingness to pitch in.
